textBox.richText: When it comes to whether video games are art, people are very divided.  One one side, you have people who argue that it isn’t a proper art form because it doesn’t fit the mold that other, more mature, art forms fit into.  On the other extreme, you have people who argue that video games are a wholly new art form.  Then there are people like Jim Preston (a game designer) who think that the whole question is silly: To think that there is a single, generally agreed upon concept of art is to get it precisely backwards. Americans' attitude towards art is profoundly divided, disjointed and confused; and my message to garners is to simply ignore the "is-it-art?" debate altogether.  I’ve always agreed with Jim Preston, and in this post, I’ll detail why. Those who see video games as an art form, are often reluctant to consider them a “true” art form.  In other words, people often consider video games a “lesser” art form next to more traditional art forms such as literature, painting, film & music. The silly thing is that video games are ALL of those traditional art forms combined in a format that allows for interactivity.  In other words, video games are a mixture of different art forms that are combined using gameplay mechanics. So, why do people still argue that video games are not art?  I imagine that it is their lack of understanding of the video game medium itself - their desire to over generalize video games into something that fits a particular mold, when in reality, video games are as diverse and complex as human society.  These same people often try to generalize human society as well ;-) But seriously.....if we were to define video games as art, we’d need to have some sort of solid definition of what art is.....and people disagree vehemently on the definition of art.  For me, art is one of those things that is nearly impossible to describe, but you know it when you experience it.  When you see a picture or hear a song that stirs emotion that the designer intended, you think "Wow - that is art!"  And I’ve had many “Wow - that is art!” moments playing video games over the years.  Just think of when Halo came out - stunning visuals of an alien landscape, stirring music, and a plot that made you feel like you were in the middle of a sci-fi novel.  Halo is art. The classifications that we've traditionally applied to other works of art don't necessarily fit the video game mold.  And why should they?  Gamers today have this immense vocabulary that describes the features of the games that they play - they can describe at length why a particular RPG (Role Playing Game) is better at fostering communication compared to another, or why a specific FPS (First Person Shooter) makes you feel as if you are fighting a lost war in some foreign time and country.  It's as complex as the vocabulary used to describe the features of an impressionist painting or orchestral piece. So why would there be a need to attempt to describe video games using traditional art terminology?  We’ve already got that terminology.... So, in many ways, I agree with Jim Preston - we should avoid talking about video games as art in the traditional sense altogether.  Video games are an immersive medium that allows far more freedom of expression than traditional art forms.  They can be abstract.  They can be real.  They can allow the player to experience empathy, reverence, excitement, sadness, joy, and relaxation.  Visuals, gameplay and music combine together to make that happen in a way that is unique to video games. Not only are video games art, they are a new kind of medium that begs for a more impressive label.  So instead of calling them art, we could call them art++  ;-)
